title: How to Set Up a Desktop Micro Studio

steps.headline: Select the part of your desktop that you want to use and clean it up.
steps.description: You will find it much easier to clean than your garage!

steps.headline: With your adhesive tape, apply one side of the tape to your selected background.
steps.description: If you want this to be a little less permanent, use thumbtacks instead, or perhaps poster tack.

steps.headline: Fasten the background sheet to the cleared place on your desktop.
steps.description:
Fasten it towards the top of the allotted space and to the rear, as shown in the image. Position an LED at the top to throw out light onto the objects being photographed. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4c\/Set-Up-a-Desktop-Micro-Studio-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-459px-Set-Up-a-Desktop-Micro-Studio-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/4c\/Set-Up-a-Desktop-Micro-Studio-Step-3Bullet1.jpg\/v4-759px-Set-Up-a-Desktop-Micro-Studio-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

\n<\/p>


\n<\/p><\/div>"}

steps.headline: Attach some type of reflective lining to the 'sides' of your studio.
steps.description: You might want to find some way to be able to change it up, find a less permanent method than taping, such as poster tack. Either that, or just cover up the white reflective material when needed.

steps.headline: Start experimenting.
steps.description:
Find something small to figure out what works best. In this photo, a glass kitty is curled up on a white background. Not very easy to see. In this photo, a different color background was slotted into the micro studio, and you can see the object much more easily. {"smallUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/48\/1261952-5b1.jpg\/v4-459px-1261952-5b1.jpg","bigUrl":"https:\/\/www.wikihow.com\/images\/thumb\/4\/48\/1261952-5b1.jpg\/v4-759px-1261952-5b1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

text:
Select the part of your desktop that you want to use and clean it up. You will find it much easier to clean than your garage! With your adhesive tape, apply one side of the tape to your selected background. If you want this to be a little less permanent, use thumbtacks instead, or perhaps poster tack. Fasten the background sheet to the cleared place on your desktop. Fasten it towards the top of the allotted space and to the rear, as shown in the image. Position an LED at the top to throw out light onto the objects being photographed. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4c/Set-Up-a-Desktop-Micro-Studio-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/v4-459px-Set-Up-a-Desktop-Micro-Studio-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/4c/Set-Up-a-Desktop-Micro-Studio-Step-3Bullet1.jpg/v4-759px-Set-Up-a-Desktop-Micro-Studio-Step-3Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Attach some type of reflective lining to the 'sides' of your studio. You might want to find some way to be able to change it up, find a less permanent method than taping, such as poster tack. Either that, or just cover up the white reflective material when needed. Start experimenting. Find something small to figure out what works best. In this photo, a glass kitty is curled up on a white background. Not very easy to see. In this photo, a different color background was slotted into the micro studio, and you can see the object much more easily. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/48/1261952-5b1.jpg/v4-459px-1261952-5b1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/48/1261952-5b1.jpg/v4-759px-1261952-5b1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":306,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":506.31868131868134,"licensing":"
